ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Plasmonic modes of nanobox, nanocage, and nanoframe

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: The scattering, absorption, and extinction cross sections of Ag nanobox, nanocage, and nanoframe illuminated by a polarized plane wave are studied using the finite element method. Our numerical results show that the plasmon modes (dipole and quadrupole modes) of a single Ag nanocage are red-shifted as the thickness of the wall decreases. In addition, the plasmon modes of porous nanocage and nanoframe are red-shifted relative to the nanobox as the surface porosity of nanocage increases. In particular, the wavelengths at the peaks of these modes almost linearly depend on the surface porosity. Moreover, the scattering efficiency of the dipole mode is much higher than the absorption one. The former is broadband, while the latter narrowband. These modes are confirmed by their far-field scattering patterns, and the corresponding surface electric field distributions are also investigated.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: The synthesis methods of Ag or Au nanocubes have been developed in the last decade [1–3]. Moreover, the Ag or Au, Au–Ag volume-porous nanoboxes, surface-porous nanocages, and nanoframes were synthesized by controlling the molar ratio of the etchant (e.g., HAuCl4) and reaction time properly recently [4–12]. Basically, the nanobox is a harrowed nanocube, and the nanocage is a cubic nanostructure with both the volume and surface porosity. In this paper, we are motivated to study theoretically the relationship between the plasmonic properties and the surface porosity for the face-holed nanocages. The local surface plasmon resonances (LSPR) of these metallic nanoparticles (NPs) depend on their sizes, volume porosity, and surface porosity. The previous studies have shown that the plasmon modes of nanoboxes are strongly dependent on the ratio of the edge length to the thickness of metal wall [10, 11]. In this paper, we focus on the study of the plasmon modes of porous nanocage related to the surface porosity. In particular, the near-field and far-field responses of Ag nanocage illuminated by a plane wave at the dipole and quadrupole modes are investigated [13]. Because the optical window of biological tissue is within the near infrared (NIR) regime, the porous nanocages have a merit to red-shift their plasmon mode within NIR regime by varying the volume and surface porosities. Besides these optical properties, these porous metal NPs have the potential as a drug delivery system for pharmaceutical nanotechnology to carry drugs inside the pore [14]. Subsequently, we might trigger the nanosystem to release drug shining NIR light at a specific site in vivo. This photothermal mechanism is due to the LSPR absorption and heating. As a result, these metallic NPs possess the wavelength-selectivity for performing photothermal function [15]. On the other hand, the scattering performances of these NPs at the LSPR make them a contrast agent with wavelength dependence [15]. The biomedical applications of porous metallic nanocages, based on the multifunctional merits, are growing more recently. Consequently, these NPs have a potential as the theranostic (diagnostic combined with therapeutic) agents because of the strong scattering and absorption properties [16].

To simulate the scattering and absorption responses of nanocube, nanobox, nanocage, and nanoframe numerically, the discrete dipole approximation (DDA) has been used [11, 12, 17, 18]. The other numerical methods, e.g., the finite difference time domain (FDTD) method [19] and finite element method (FEM) [20], have also been used to study the plasmonic behaviors of metallic nanocubes. In this paper, we use a commercial FEM code (HFSS, ANSOFT) to simulate the near-field and far-field responses of nanocages of different surface porosities.

Section1.Heading: Numerical method
Section1.Para:
Figure 1 shows the configuration of a porous nanocage with six square holes on the faces illuminated by a polarized plane wave. The edge length, wall thickness, and hole length are denoted by a, t, and l, respectively. For a nanobox, there is no face hole. If the ratio of l/a is larger than 0.5, the nanocage is normally called a nanoframe. Without loss of generality, the plane wave is assumed to be normal incident and x-polarized; the wavenumber vector is k=−k e
z . The total electromagnetic field in the surrounding medium is the sum of the incident and scattered fields; E=E
i +E
s , H=H
i +H
s . Here, the superscripts “i” and “s” denote the incident and scattered parts, respectively. A commercial FEM code (HFSS, ANSOFT) is used to simulate the electromagnetic field induced by a polarized plane wave normally incident upon one face of a nanobox or nanocage. Throughout the paper, the time factor is exp(iωt). The frequency-dependent permittivity of Ag is referred to [21], which is a complex function, ε Ag=ε′−iε″. For a lossy material, the imaginary part of permittivity should satisfy the relation, ε Ag>0. After the full electromagnetic field is calculated, the absorption power of a nanocage is the integration of the volume loss density in the metal 1
$$ P_{a}=\int_V\rho_{v}\,dv, $$ where V is the total volume of the metal, and the volume loss density is 2
$$ \rho_{v} = \frac{\omega \varepsilon ''}{2}| \mathbf{E}|^{2}. $$ Equation (2) illustrates that the imaginary part of the permittivity of Ag, ε″, causes the dissipation of light, the ohmic loss. The scattering power of the scattered light from the nanocage, the energy flow rate to the far field, in terms of the Poynting vector, is defined as 3
$$ P_{s} = \frac{1}{2}\operatorname{Re} \biggl\{ \int_{S} \bigl( \mathbf{E}^{s} \times \bar{\mathbf{H}}^{s} \bigr) \,d\mathbf{a} \biggr\}, $$ where the bar over H is the conjugate symbol, Re denotes the real part, and the integral surface S is any closed surface enclosing the whole nanocage. Subsequently, dividing the absorption and scattering powers by the average energy flux of the incident plane wave, the scattering cross section (SCS) and absorption cross section (ACS) are obtained, and then the extinction cross section (ECS) is obtained by summing SCS and ACS. These parameters are wavelength-dependent. These values are normalized by the projected area, a 2, to obtain the corresponding efficiencies [20].
Fig. 1
Configuration of nanocage with face-holes illuminated by a polarized plane wave. a: edge length. t: thickness. l: hole length

Section1.Heading: Results and discussion
Section1.Para:
In the following simulations, the edge length of nanobox or nanocage is a=80 nm. The surrounding medium is air. The SC, ACS, and ECS efficiencies of a single Ag nanobox, nanocage, and nanoframe of t=10 nm with different surface holes are shown in Fig. 2(a) l=0 nm, (b) l=16 nm, (c) l=24 nm, and (d) l=48 nm. The normal incident plane wave is x-polarized, as shown in Fig. 1. All these values are normalized by the projected cross section of nanocage; a 2. We also calculate the optical responses of a thinner nanocage with t=8 nm and l=24 nm, as shown in Fig. 3. In these spectra, the first and second peaks correspond to the dipole and quadrupole modes. The wavelengths of the plasmon bands of nanocages and nanoframes of different thicknesses (t=8 nm or 10 nm) are listed in Table 1. It is obvious that these plasmon modes (dipole and quadrupole) of nanocages and nanoframes are red-shifted from those of the nanobox. In addition, the plasmon modes of a nanocage with a thinner wall arered-shifted from those of a thicker one. From Figs. 2 and 3, the third mode (so-called sextupole mode) is also observed for these nanocages, e.g., the peak of the sextupole mode is at 404 nm for the nanocage of t=10 nm and l=24 nm. For these NPs, the first band (dipole mode) is broadband, and the higher order (e.g., quadrupole) modes narrowband. Moreover, we study the relationship between these wavelengths of the peaks of these modes and the surface porosity, α
s =(l/a)2. The wavelengths of the dipole and quadrupole modes of nanocage versus the surface porosity are plotted in Fig. 4 for t=8 nm and 10 nm. Our results show that the wavelengths of these plasmon modes are almost linearly dependent on the surface porosity. For the nanocages of t=10 nm, the values of these wavelengths (λ 1, λ 2) of the dipole and quadrupole modes in nanometer against the surface porosity can be approximately expressed as 4
$$\begin{aligned} &{\lambda_{1} = 519 + 807\alpha_{s},} \end{aligned}$$
5
$$\begin{aligned} &{\lambda_{2} = 442 + 527\alpha_{s}.} \end{aligned}$$ For the cases of t=8 nm, the linear approximations of the modal wavelength versus the surface porosity are 6
$$\begin{aligned} &{\lambda_{1} = 555 + 817\alpha_{s},} \end{aligned}$$
7
$$\begin{aligned} &{\lambda_{2} = 457 + 591\alpha_{s}.} \end{aligned}$$ In comparison of the above equations, the slopes for the thinner nanocages is little larger than those of the thicker ones. These results demonstrate that both the volume porosity and surface porosity are useful to adjust the plasmon bands; the larger these porosities, the more the red-shift of these plasmon bands. The volume porosity is the volume ratio, α
v =(a−2t)3/a 3, related to the thickness of the Ag wall. For example, the dipole band of a nanocage (t=10 nm) with a tiny surface porosity of 0.04 (l=16 nm) is red-shifted as large as 28 nm.

Furthermore, we study the near-field and far-field behaviors of a single nanocage at the plasmon modes. The 3D plot of the surface electric field and the near-field electric field distribution in x–y plane of a nanocage excited at the dipole mode (547 nm) are plotted in Figs. 5(a) and (b), where t=10 nm and l=16 nm. Additionally, the 3D spherical plot of the far field scattering pattern and the cross sections in x–z and y–z planes are plotted in Figs. 5(c) and (d), respectively. Here, the far-field scattering pattern is defined as 8
$$ \big| r^{2}\mathbf{E}^{s} \times \bar{\mathbf{H}}^{s} \cdot \mathbf{e}_{r} \big|\quad \mbox{as}\ r \to \infty, $$ which is a function of the observing angle. In Eq. (8), r is the distance from the center of nanocage. The results of the quadrupole mode (460 nm) are plotted in Fig. 6. The cross section of the far-field scattering pattern in x–z plane shows that there are two lobes (see Fig. 5). This is an indication of the dipole mode. In contrast, there are four lobes in the pattern of the second mode, indicating that it is a quadrupole mode. We also simulate the near-field and far-field optical responses for a thinner nanocage of t=8 nm with a larger surface porosity of 0.09 (l=24 nm) at the dipole mode (625 nm) and quadrupole mode (513 nm), as shown in Figs. 7 and 8, respectively. The patterns and distributions of Figs. 7 and 8 at these plasmon modes are nearly the same with Figs. 5 and 6. Recently, the dark-field hyperspectral microscopy and spectroscopy have been developed to measure the scattering spectrum of a single nanoparticle [22]. The information of the far-field scattering pattern of a single NP will be useful for the measurement.
Fig. 5
(a) Surface electric field, (b) electric field distribution in x–y plane, (c) 3D spherical plot of far field scattering pattern, and (d) the cross sections of scattering pattern in x–z and y–z planes for Ag nanocage (a=80 nm, t=10 nm, l=16 nm) illuminated by an x-polarized plane wave of λ=547 nm (dipole mode) in air
Fig. 6
(a) Surface electric field, (b) near-field electric field distribution in x–y plane, (c) 3D spherical plot of far field scattering pattern, and (d) the cross sections of scattering pattern in x–z and y–z planes for Ag nanocage (a=80 nm, t=10 nm, l=16 nm) illuminated by an x-polarized plane wave of λ=460 nm (quadrupole mode) in air
Fig. 7
(a) Surface electric field distribution, and (b) far-field scattering pattern in x–z and y–z planes of nanocage (a=80 nm, t=8 nm, l=24 nm) at 625 nm; dipole mode
Fig. 8
(a) Surface electric field distribution, and (b) far-field scattering pattern in x–z and y–z planes of nanocage (a=80 nm, t=8 nm, l=24 nm) at 513 nm; quadrupole mode

Section1.Heading: Conclusion
Section1.Para: Our numerical results show that the wavelengths of the plasmonic dipole and quadrupole modes of Ag nanocage are almost linearly dependent on the surface porosity; the larger the surface porosity, the more the red-shift of these modes. For a nanoframe, whose face-hole length is larger than a half of the edge length, the dipole modes is within the NIR regime. Moreover, the plasmon modes of a thinner nanocage are red-shifted from those of a thicker one. At the dipole mode of a nanocage, the scattering efficiency is much higher than the absorption one. This feature indicates that the dipole mode of nanocages can be utilized as a contrast agent for imaging, e.g., dark-field microscopy and two-photon microscopy. In contrast, the absorption efficiency is higher than the scattering one at the quadrupole mode. We found that both the volume porosity and surface porosity are useful to adjust the plasmon bands of the porous nanocages; the larger these porosities, the more the red-shift of these plasmon band. The volume porosity is the third power of (a−2t)/a, while the surface porosity the second power of l/a. In particular, the relationship of the wavelength at the peak of these bands with the surface porosity is almost linear for nanobox, nanocage, and nanoframe. Based on these characterizations, the configuration of nanocages can be tailored to control their plasmon modes and the corresponding scattering and absorption efficiencies on demand.

Acknowledgments.Heading: Acknowledgement
Acknowledgments.SimplePara: The research was supported by Chang Gung University (BMRP892).
